for one thing: it empowers you to make better decisions even when it might not have occurred to you to involve an LLM. For example, most people don't know that a single queue with N servers is faster than N single-server queues. My knowledge of complexity helps me find the shortest checkout line.

posts.text:
A lot of people, including me, were wondering how an IRB could ever approve this study. 

The answer is that no IRB did. The person who â€œsigned offâ€ on approval from the only ethics board that reviewed it had resigned three years earlier. His signature was used without his knowledge.
As it was before, so it is now and will be forevermore: the real art underlying CS is learning how to manage complexity.

One of the main checks on authoritarianism, rather than any formal power structure, has always been that you need people to do things, and people have their own private morality.

I wonder if the old "hashing trick" line of research might not have results that could be useful to you here. I think that line of work essentially operated in the same "boolean cube" regime as your thm.12, but without assuming a fixed k. Attached an example of work that you might find relevant.

reply_context.text: Here, celebrated results (Candes and Tao, Donoho) imply that we can store m features in d = O(k log(m/k)) dimensions, where k is the sparsity (# of features active per input). This means that d dimensions can store an exponential number of features (superposition).
